awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Rank Aggregation with Heterogeneous Information Sources: Efficient Algorithms and Fundamental Limits
awd_abstract_narration:
While advances in the ability to collect and store data have made large data sets commonplace, these data sets increasingly consist of information obtained from different sources with various data types and properties that impede the ability to extract knowledge and make decisions. This project focuses on inferring the ranking of a set of objects from heterogeneous datasets with arbitrary noise, which is also known as rank aggregation with heterogeneous information sources. The developed algorithms will be made publicly available as open source software tools, and will significantly expand the applicability of rank aggregation to real-world problems, such as data fusion, information retrieval, crowd-sourcing, recommendation systems, as well as social choice and voting. This project will also provide educational and training opportunities and exposure to sophisticated statistical tools, rigorous theoretical analysis, and the empirical work of extracting knowledge from large heterogeneous data sets. 

In this project, based on statistical models of data, efficient and scalable rank aggregation algorithms for various settings will be developed along with performance guarantees and fundamental limits, in three complementary research thrusts. First, it will develop rank aggregation algorithms based on flexible latent probabilistic models that exploit side information and allow both ordinal and numerical data types. It will also provide information-theoretic lower bounds on the performance of such algorithms. Second, it will design robust algorithms for latent probabilistic models in which the unknown parameters are a superposition of many structured parameters, and models in which data can be corrupted by arbitrary noise. Finally, the problem of inferring a ranking through interactive bandit algorithms will be studied. This project aims to push the frontier of rank aggregation research, and can potentially advance research in machine learning, nonconvex optimization and information theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Rank aggregation, the problem of inferring the ranking of a set of items based on noisy pairwise comparisons and partial orderings, has a wide range of applications, from strategic decision-making to recommender systems used to generate playlists and newsfeeds. This project focused on developing efficient algorithms that perform rank aggregation under realistic assumptions, applicable to real-world datasets, especially when the data is heterogeneous and collected from a variety of sources. Mathematically, the properties of the input data are described via probabilistic models that represent the accuracy, as well as dependencies and inconsistencies among different data elements. Models that make strong assumptions about the data are easier to analyze but may only work well under limited conditions. In contrast, more flexible models are broadly applicable but pose greater technical challenges. Our research explored both settings, progressively moving from models with strong assumptions to more flexible models, thus advancing methods for handling inconsistencies within and across data sources.


A key contribution of this project was the development of algorithms for ranking when comparisons come from multiple sources with varying reliability. This includes both passive methods, where we do not have control over what items are compared, and active methods, where the algorithm strategically selects which comparisons to make. In the active setting, we studied both the sample complexity, i.e., how much data is needed to make reliable decisions, and regret, which is relevant for applications such as recommender systems, measuring the algorithm’s ability to learn user preferences while simultaneously providing suitable recommendations. We provided performance guarantees for our algorithms and developed bounds on what is achievable by any algorithm. We showed via analysis and experiments that our algorithms improve upon the state-of-the-art methods in a range of settings.

From an educational perspective, the project provided research training in machine learning, optimization, and probabilistic modeling to multiple graduate students. Research findings have been integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses and used to illustrate key concepts in machine learning. Our results were disseminated through top-tier conferences such as AAAI, AISTATS, ICLR, ICML, and NeurIPS, as well as preprints on arXiv and open-source software on GitHub. The project's findings have contributed to a better theoretical understanding of rank aggregation and practical methods that can improve a wide range of applications.
